review_title: Great place to work, great environment
pros: Northwestern is heavily focused on academic excellence, but not only that, there are a lot of good people there. I enjoyed my experience working in Civil and Environmental Engineering. Pay is decent and hours are standard:  8:30AM to 5 PM. I enjoyed the many training courses and interacting with students.
cons: Not a ton of room for advancement and McCormick is very concerned about people who "apply to too many openings." Apparently that is the sign of an indiscriminate job hopper.

pros: Science environment is very good.
cons: You can't get a raise because your PI decides to. You get to be stuck with your 2% northwestern annual raise, no matter what. Good thing though, it makes you want to go out from your post-doc. And now with the new overtime rules. You have 2-3-4-5 year post-docs earning as much as a new 0year post-doc

pros: Work - life balance is feasable here, espeically if your are interested in pursuing a masters progam at the University, if you can get in and afford it.
cons: Respect is given based on length of service versus knowledge.

review_title: It is a place if you do want to have a lot of freedom on scientific research
pros: a lot of resources such as core facilities, close to clinical environment which you can access the data or samples from patients, a nice scientific community which you can share your brain with,
cons: salary is low comparing with other private universities and NIH and I guess it is because they think they are northwestern. It just like people still go to Harvard if they don't offer you tenure track position.

review_title: Worked with a great group of people
job_title: Research Technologist I in Chicago, IL
pros: benefits seemed pretty good, worked with some very competent people. working in a lab, I mostly interacted with a small group of people who were primarily chosen by my PI, and he did a good job of picking people who work well together.
cons: some of the systems are archaic, unwieldy, and entirely inefficient (ordering systems, etc), and it wasn't always made clear what work was the responsibility of the lab vs what was the responsibility of the business office or other parts of the university

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: The campus is very nice. It next to the lake. There are many fun activities in the summer. The professors here are very well-known and talented. Many big name in the field of computational mechanics. They are all great professors. They are collaborative. There are many knowledgeable colleagues.
cons: Unfortunately the weather in Winter is really cold and windy. The atmosphere/ working environment is quite stressful. Most of the PhD students have to work more than 60 hours per week. Some professors don't allow students to have internship during PhD study.

review_title: Happy I was given the opportunity to work there, happier that I left.
pros: Great environment and great people.
cons: For a top notch business school one would think strategy and communication would be at the forefront.  This is not the case.  This lack of strategy and poor communication trickles down to the individual departments and causes big inefficiencies.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: It's a top university. It pays more compared to other universities in the area. It has great working environment, located in peaceful area and it's really a safe place.
cons: Being a PhD student is the most difficult thing in life. It is full of stress and you get paid low. At the same time your peers at industry get's at least 5 times more salary than you and enjoy better life.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Evanston, IL
pros: Northwestern has a top tier research environment with access to exceptional facilities and knowledgeable colleagues across fields and opportunities for collaboration.
cons: The location is difficult to access because it is rather far outside of the city of Chicago, leading to lengthy commute times. The surrounding city of Evanston is rather expensive to live in as an option.

pros: Great mentoring combined with good facilities makes the graduate experience enjoyable and rewarding.  There is also great access to the world's leaders in a number of fields.
cons: The bureaucracy can be overwhelming at times.  There is a definite power structure that people fight to keep intact regardless of how little sense it makes.

review_title: Fair somewhat-high turnover in some departments.
pros: Management not that bright. Stressfull. Can't say there was much I like or enjoyed. It was a job that allowed me to grow in some areas and develop new skills, but for the most part I felt out of touch with the people there an expected more knowledgeable people to surround me. The job experience is what you make of it. Nothing more nothing less.
cons: Stressfull, have to learn a lot of the job on your own.

pros: Working as a research assistant provides you with some spending money and some basic quantitative and qualitative analytic skills.
cons: There's a lot of variability in terms of whether you actually get to have a hand in decisions and the thought process behind the labs/studies you're working with, or if you're just there to handle busywork.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: Relatively good benefits (compared to other universities) which include health, vision and dental insurance, matched 401(k); access to excellent facilities (genomics, imaging)
cons: Current dean seems to care about money more than investing in science. We have had a couple of faculty searches wherein the dean turned down our top choices because they didn't have their own grants even though the position is for new faculty. Graduate students and postdocs are a bit apathetic and don't go outside of their labs to learn or ask people for expertise.

pros: It was a great way to connect with professors. I was able to get some hands on experience and learn research was my area of interest. I appreciated the interest in my academic and professional development.
cons: Since it was a work-study position pay was not fantastic, but more than adequate for the flexibility it allowed during the school year.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Evanston, IL
pros: Flexible hours, ample opportunities for collaborations, access to research equipment, machine shop training and access, 403b retirement contributions (voluntary available immediately, 5% matched and 5% unmatched available after 1 year of employment)
cons: Parking is a always a zoo and my particular research group attitude and work-life balance was poor.  The business office lost my paperwork for contract renewal which messed up my paychecks, retirement contribution schedule, and kicked me out of systems for keycard access; no apology was ever issued for the hassle this caused.

pros: I work in a great environment where everyone is friendly and willing to help. Working at and attending Northwestern as a student is the best thing to ever happen to me because of its diversity, the opportunities it offers, and the exposure to the business world.
cons: I cannot identify any cons. Northwestern truly is the place to be for a great education and for the opportunities it has to offer.

review_title: I have had a pleasant experience working in one of Northwestern's labs
pros: Among the smartest people I have ever met, with flexible hours and very intellectually demanding. I would highly recommend joining a lab here at Northwestern
cons: Although the work can be very demanding, sometimes your supervisors don't care that much at all and the work can become tedious at times.

review_title: Organization is great, experience may vary by department
pros: The university has progressive policies with benefits and work/life balance, which make it a great place to work overall.
cons: My department ignores employee conflicts and just hopes that they will work themselves out.  Constant changes to procedures and direction make it hard to know exactly what you're supposed to be doing, and no one is ever really held accountable to make sure the prescribed policies are followed.  All in all, this creates a hectic and frustration work environment.

pros: Overall Northwestern has great perks including education benefits,  very good health benefits, excellent retirement match after 3 years. Depending on your department, you may be working on interesting projects.
cons: My department was a mess! Leadership was so disconnected from the work being done. There was a general dissatisfaction with the way things were managed, despite incredibly talented, hard-working teammates.  While the benefits are good, there was no way in my department to advance and raises were a joke (1-3% max).

pros: My direct supervisor was great and the campus is beautiful.
cons: There was no work/life balance, and I was told to get a nanny instead of daycare so that I wouldn't have to stay home when my kids were sick.  I was bullied by a coworker and expected to just put up with it because 'that's how she is'.

pros: There are a lot of great research opportunities as an undergraduate. I have worked here as a research assistant for a biology laboratory for disease therapies for atherosclerosis. My mentors are helpful, and I have learned a substantial amount about science research from the job. Plus, it looks great on a resume!
cons: The school in general is very demanding on economics and pre-medical students. Definitely not an easy school, by any means.

pros: Northwestern University has great job recruiting and professional development options, as well as world-class instrumentation and facilities. It also offers a competitive graduate stipend.
cons: The culture among many of the faculty and research staff is highly adversarial and politically charged. Researchers here move to the head of the pack more often as a result of conniving and manipulation than creativity, hard work, and talent.

pros: Great Benefits, Health & Educational.  NU seems to be growing in the right direction
cons: Very difficult to rise through organization.  Top level management doesn't assist in development of employee.   It would be a great place to be a mid level or senior level manager, however, as a young professional there is a lack of mentorship and lack of desire to assist employee development

review_title: Not as great as you think
job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Prestigious university, lots of opportunity to learn in research.
cons: No way to move up.  Everything happens behind closed doors and you can never get a straight answer from HR.  Very discouraging.  Their policies do not allow upwards movement for good employees.  Very easy to do a medial job and never be reprimanded.

review_title: Great benefits, pay could be better
job_title: Choose A State in Chicago, IL
pros: Northwestern's benefits are great.  Health insurance coverage is impressive.  When you need time off, they are flexible.  They provide a healthy amount of sick days, personal days, and vacation days.
cons: Some of the cons of working in a university setting include lower pay than working at a corporate company and little opportunity for new opportunities/raises.  The university is hesitant in providing promotions, which can be a huge disadvantage if you're looking to grow into a new position.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Northwestern University ranks among the premier Universities in the Nation. It is located on a beautiful campus, and offers good stipends to graduate students.
cons: One of the biggest drawbacks is lack of diversity in the student body and lack of support by faculty or faculty that is easily accessible.

review_title: Excellence at Northwestern does not extend beyond the classroom and labs
pros:
Location
Diversity of entry-level opportunity
Access to cultural, educational, athletic & recreational opportunities
Interaction with students & faculty
Resources (could easily make itself a better place to work if it wanted to)
cons:
Pay/benefits are not competitive
Opportunities for advancement
Relationship to surrounding communities of Chicago & Evanston
Staff culture
Attitude of Central Admin & Students/Faculty to staff

pros: The campus is great--particularly in the summer--and the research is cutting-edge with many experts at your disposal. Collaboration in research is highly encouraged. Depending on the adviser and the field, the other graduate students are sociable. Proximity to Chicago is also a plus.
cons: The Northwestern system is extremely bureaucratic and de-centralized, making any communication with other parts of the university a pain, particularly in the reimbursement of work-related expenses. Again, depending on the adviser, the connections post-graduation can be quite narrow.

job_title: Program Assistant II in Evanston, IL
pros: Big, nice, clean office. Great place to meet other young, smart people. Made good friends. Lots of opportunities for internal training.
cons: People can be a little unreasonable, very hard to move up, low-pay.

pros: The people who you work for are some of the smartest people in their profession out there.  They are also doing cutting edge research
cons: Some of the work that they have you do can be tedious at times and the projects can take a long time to complete

review_title: Good job, great benefits, tough manager to work for...
pros: Benefits were very good; the people were just as good to work with.
cons: I had a VP that micromanaged and over the long term, it wore me out. Additionally, the VP was a politicizing figure that tried to make everyone happy and many times didn't make anyone really happy.

review_title: A great University to work for.
pros:
Great benefits, the tuition reimbursement for faculty is generous with a 40% reduction in tuition if your child attends NU, or you can apply that amount to another University.

It is easy to meet incentive goals for bonuses, although the bonus are relatively conservative.
cons: The starting salaries for junior faculty are low and not easy to increase salary.  bonus is easy to qualify for, but are modest in amount.

job_title: Research Project Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Fantastic benefits, potential for growth if you're on the right track, good name to have on a resume
cons: Pay is not ideal - merit increases are inconsequential, very bureaucratic, underutilize staff and their education levels, frequently will work to the bottom of your degree - not the top,

pros: Lots of resources, vacation, tuition reimbursement after 1 year, beautiful environment, friendly staff.
cons: No room to grow, fear of job elimination due to 100 million budget cut, inflexible management structure, low status if you are non-faculty, slow to response and action for anything, lots of internal politics and in-fighting especially in the IT Administrative Systems unit, poor IT management leadership, not a true diversified environment.

job_title: Senior Training Specialist in Evanston, IL
pros: Nice benefit package 10% 403b matching 5% without you contributing anything. Nice professional development budget.
cons:
The different units are decentralized so networking is difficult because you don't know who is where and what they do. 

Every unit has an agenda, you have to get things done through buy-in and influence. Policy can be hard to come by.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Evanston, IL
pros: Nice environment right beside lake Michigan. My adviser is also pretty nice and creative. The life here is enjoyable too.
cons: The winter is cold and long, and the living expense in evanston is generally high. The limited income as a postdoctoral fellow gives me hard time to support a family.

review_title: Took it for the experience, Wish I made more $$
pros: I work with a world renowned doctor and have learned a lot
cons: I don't make a lot of $ and won't unless I get promoted in a different department. They pretty much take advantage of the fact that you want to work there to get experience for grad/ medical school

review_title: Great Place to Work! Amazing Benefits!
pros: Great community feel, engaged leadership, supportive of professional and personal development, amazing benefits.  NU is committed to excellence and it shows!
cons: The only con I can think of is that there is no easy way to commute to Evanston.  But that is not an NU problem.

pros: The work was hard, but fun. You need to sleep while the kids are at class to stay sane. Be friends with the Coordinators and you will be fine.
cons: You will be worked hard.  Time of or alone is very hard to come by.  Rest when you can and don't make your kids hate you.

pros: People are friendly and open. The management is very supportive of course innovation. Students behave themselves generally and study hard. Full of resources if you want to expand your academic career. Nice scenery.
cons: The internet system is not stable every day. Classrooms are slightly insufficient because there are too many students. The winter here is too cold (chill factor is terrible)!

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Great education,collaborative, great environment with smart people. Moreover, i have to say that i have improved in many aspect including as a human being from the constant feedback from my seniors.
cons: Pressure to perform and the need to TA undergrads, the need to bend to their wills take away from the educational value.

pros: There are many amazing scientists and interesting research being done, with access to advanced equipment and facilities. There are good benefits, too. Northwestern's good reputation promises better chances of getting funded for research, and there are plenty of knowledgeable people around that are willing to help with research problems.
cons: Many of the PIs that employ techs have little to no management skills or experience, and sometimes labs can get underfunded because there isn't enough grant money coming in.

pros:
Best academic research facilities bar none. Also, a great environment where collaboration is highly encouraged and expected.
Great culture, people, benefits. also lots of support for staff esp. child care
cons: Winters are a little long. Evanston is a little expensive. That's mostly it, I just have to somehow write 20 words minimum otherwise this wont get posted and I cant see other useful reviews but seriously NU is an awesome place to do a postdoc in chemistry.

pros: The benefits are outstanding at this institution. Highly intellectual environment with the opportunity to collaborate on forward thinking projects.
cons: Very political environment. Advances depend on who you know. Ability to have work life balance most likely depends on the department with some departments being very high stress. Compensation was average, but offset by benefits.

pros: Wonderful opportunities for furthering your education through undergraduate and graduate coursework, for the most part, very competent and smart colleagues who work hard.
cons: Decentralized organization - certain schools have better resources than others (i.e. Kellogg and the professional schools vs. everyone else); upward mobility is more limited and you may have to leave the school and come back in order to advance

pros: The culture here is moderately laid back compared to some other top tier schools. But if you want a very rigorous experience you can choose a PI who will create that environment as well.
cons: Some students seem to take forever to finish. Especially in Micro-Immuno. They take 7+ on average.

review_title: Great benefits & flexibility, but monetize these for comparison!
pros: Benefits & flexible schedule: Great insurance. Good, portable tuition benefit. Child care matching $s, etc...  Beautiful campus, great students!
cons:
Low salary, lower in status within the university (for office space, etc.) than tenure track faculty and even staff members. 

Many people are afraid to give up benefits and find employment elsewhere. But really, put a $ amount on the benefits and negotiate with a potential employer to get a better deal.

pros: Great place to be for working with top students. Terrific brand name for your CV. Beautiful location, just be ready for cold winters. Depending on your position, solid facilities.
cons: They know their brand value, so prepare for some sticker shock in your pay. Faculty walk on water, staff less so. Be prepared to have to play politics to get into the right circles (channel your inner middle school self in trying to get in with the cool kids).

pros: NU pays employees relatively well and is interested in the growth of the institution. The values here are strong and teh faculty is excellent even though the administration is not always interested in the best needs of students.
cons: NU is primarily interested in building new builds and the politics of the institution can be overwhelming

pros: Everything is close to home and the employers are cognizant that we are students. Always willing to let you take more shifts and don't baby you.
cons: Boss will tell you that you are being promoted and then never follow through. Also very little given when hardships arise.

pros: Within Education NU is a hard name to beat in the Chicagoland area.  It is a wonderful college campus with a great location close to the lake.  There are many individuals who care greatly about the work they do.
cons: Working in Education is different than the private sector - be prepared for that adjustment.  There can be huge swings in terms of performance levels from teams to teams and there isn't always a "next" career move.

review_title: My review is in relation to the dept. I worked in....
pros: Great benefits, easy atmosphere, terrific location
cons: The workload was just too much. Management expected you to do the work for more than two positions without ever increasing pay...the “raises” are little more than bumps...

pros: Highly ranked private university.  Very good hospital and medical school in downtown chicago.  Engineering school is located along the Lake Michigan.  Excellent people all around.
cons: No opportunity for growth unless you are member of a faculty.  Evanston is an expensive place to live.  Benefit package is not something to boast about.

pros: Good reputation, nice campus, close to Chicago. Decent medical and retirement benefits. Stimulating work environment with possibilities for collaboration across groups and departments. Plenty of opportunities to attend classes and take advantage of the tuition reimbursement program.
cons: Compensation is not very good. Advancement opportunities within the university can be very limited. Parking can be a real problem in some areas. There is quite a bit of bureaucracy but this is probably common for most universities.

review_title: Worked in the psycho-legal studies department while working on my masters..
pros: Great research experience; interesting project
cons: Can't think of any.. the work was fun, meaningful, learned so much can't say a bad thing..

review_title: Fantastic experience with nurturing Library staff
pros: People working here genuinely care about what they do. They have a passion for books, news, history, etc. The community is strong and the work is flexible (both type and time).
cons: I haven't experienced anything even remotely significant that would lead me to associate any cons with this job.

pros: Great colleagues and grad students, feel part of a community, amazing classroom technology, can't  think of a better place to teach
cons: No benefits for part-timers, but that's  standard in academia, so it's  not really a complaint. The parking situation on the Evanston campus is terrible during the day.

pros: A challenging environment to further yourself with significant financial means for research. Potential of accomplishing great findings with a strong support of the University.
cons: Being pushed to work excessively. Very little room left for social life. Setting expectations where basically you have to spend the entire week end at work is not ok.

pros: It's a top research institution, so you have access to all the research tools you need. Funding is typically not an issue, and you work with some exceptional scientists
cons: Postdocs are definitely treated as second class workers. It is difficult to find support resources for postdoctoral fellows, and most faculty take the attitude of - I went through it this way, so you should too...

review_title: Overall a good place to work but poor university politics
pros: A great collaborative environment where people have the option to work with just about anything or anyone that they want
cons: University wide political problems resulting in poor user facilities on campus.  Additionally the undergraduates are poorly educated here as most professors are only focused on there research.

pros: a lot of very smart people. a lot of resources, great facilities. The profs are great and the lectures are very useful. The grad students dorms are horrible and expensive. it is better to live out of campus
cons: The social life is not that great. Maybe the grad school could organize more vents for students. The grad students dorms are horrible and expensive. it is better to live out of campus

review_title: Enjoyed working there, did not really help much with career.
pros: Enjoyed working with co-workers and interesting work. The research staff was generally friendly and willing to help.
cons: Very little career development, projects disorganized with little direction. Management absent mostly and interested in high risk projects. Like most research laboratories they hire a bunch of people for high risk projects and little money left over for proper budgets for projects.

job_title: Building Engineer Hey in Chicago, IL
pros: Awesome place to work awesome money awesome benefits just looking for a warmer climate, we are looking for Tucson Arizona,  Florida Tampa I have done vibration analysis over 30 years on the road doing startups dynamic balancing .
cons: Building maintenance mostly bearing replacement on it HVAC industry fans and making sure all critical fans warning signs for repair work before failure.

job_title: Public Relations Coordinator in Evanston, IL
pros: Every minute  working there was delightful.  I was the only office assistant working with 80 graduate students in the Advertising MA Program.
cons: I enjoyed the position so much that hours would pass and I never felt exhausted.

pros: Great atmosphere and leadership development programs. Lots of opportunities to grow within the university. Highly professional and pleasant staff. Amazing benefits with great vacation policy and sick time. Impossible to beat educational reimbursement.  Great Life work balancing programs. Lots of events for staff.
cons: For my role, I have to connect the dots between different departments which sometimes take too much time. Overall,  response time is still pretty fast.

review_title: Good benefits and stability, could be better in some respects
pros: Great benefits, professional colleagues, high autonomy
cons: Pay is as low as in most institutions of higher learning, very conservative leadership, currently dealing with significant, university-wide budget issues that impede retention efforts and long term strategies for staff development

review_title: I am working in Infectious department
job_title: Research Assistant in North Chicago, IL
pros: I appreciate working with the team and exposed to new knowledge and understanding about research.
cons: Northwestern is a great place but I think UNICEF would be the right place for me, having just finished my training in Global health and being working taking care of malnourished children in Africa.

job_title: User Support Specialist in Evanston, IL
pros: There are some good opportunities for career advancement if you are capable and willing to work hard at your job.
cons: While there are advancement opportunities available, it is generally up to the individual to seek them out rather than them being announced to current employees.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Collaborative environment encourages communication between students and groups--potentially leads to novel projects. The pay is relatively good in the sciences compared with other schools.
cons: The hours can be long, and many professors, while very smart, may not be the best managers. This can lead to inefficiency in the group.

review_title: An excellent, supportive place to do interdisciplinary research.
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefits, great people, good work-life balance. Lots of opportunities for collaboration and interdisciplinary research, as well as for working with people at different levels of education (undergrads, grad students, post-docs, residents, etc.).
cons: There can be a lack of communication between the disparate entities of the University and Medical School campus. This can make getting things done more difficult than they need to be.

review_title: think twice before becoming a foreign language lecturer.
pros: no teaching on thursdays. course load is two per quarter.
cons: no benefits. indentured servitude. you're not a professor nor and the differential in respect is evident.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: World class professors and excellent management.  Work environment is very nice and friendly. You are taught by the text book editors most of the time. Facilities are well maintained and very convenient
cons: It is hard to find downsides World class professors and excellent management.  Work environment is very nice and friendly. You are taught by the text book editors most of the time. Facilities are well maintained and very convenient

pros: Lots of options for commuting, good location in downtown Chicago, close proximity to restaurants and shopping, strong reputation for academic excellence, lab space is fairly new and updated.
cons: Health insurance and benefits are minimal for graduate students, progress can be impeded by school politics and bureaucracy, work experience differs from lab to lab.

pros: Working hours are pretty flexibility (most of times I've worked from home). Good environment in general. People are very friendly there.
cons: Salary is slightly low, while comparing to work in industry. Office is really small -- there's even no windows.

review_title: Good graduate school experience in the IBiS program
pros: Good research opportunities and a generally flexible work environment.  The program directors makes a genuine effort to continually improve the graduate student work/life balance.  Also, the campus in Evanston is beautiful.  A lot of the lab space is very new which makes for a pleasant and comfortable work environment.
cons: After your first year, your experience is mostly dependent on the lab you join.

review_title: Cold winters/Hot tempers/It’s as real as it gets
pros: I did my work study here as a library aide for several years. The people were a pleasure to work with. They gave me real work and responsibilities and i was able to develop a relationship with our library clients. They expect you to work hard, but you can grow here.
cons: Not much to complain about. So many jobs. Find one that is right for you.

review_title: Great place to pursue graduate studies
pros: High-profile professors including Nobel laureates. Great facilities and other resources like career consulting.
cons: Poor pay, but that's par for the course as a graduate student. Other than that there's really not much to report outside of things that come down to personal preference.

review_title: Good place to be a grad student
pros: Lots of good colleagues and access to extra curricular activities. Great campus, but could use some more options for food. Some buildings are a lot nicer to work in than others. Very flexible hours, but sometimes very long hours.
cons: Not great benefits, but that's being a graduate student. Sometimes very long hours and a lot of self-motivation is required.

pros: The faculty are understanding of student needs, and provide flexibility for students to balance work and school work. Opportunities to interact with faculty are also a plus
cons: Can be slow at times, during periods of the academic session where there is not as much traffic through administrative offices.

job_title: Senior Admission Counselor in Evanston, IL
pros: The people are wonderful.  I enjoy the atmosphere.  So much potential.  Great place to work.  Such an awesome place to be.
cons: Nothing--go 'Cats!  Appreciate the community.  Wonderful place to work--do yourself a favor and take on the challenges of working at a great university.

pros: Extremely collaborative faculty and staff.   Great culture.  Pay is market rate.  Growth mindset.  Fast-paced with not too many "lifers," which is refreshing.   Proximity to Chicago is great, but everything you need is in Evanston.
cons: The undergrad acceptance rate is <10%, so good luck getting your kids in.  Town-gown relations are getting better, but the town still doesn't appreciate all the University brings.

pros: The boss, Jackie, is very kind and accommodating with flexible student schedules. I get to meet many new students I wouldn't otherwise. Not too busy most of the time
cons: No cons really except the actual labor can sometimes be repetitive difficult and boring. The joy is from the social aspect, not the work.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Chicago, IL
pros: The benefits are pretty good offering health, dental and transit. Hiring process is smooth when HR staff is involved.
cons:
Pay is on the low for an area with such a high cost of living. 
Post-doctoral position is dependent on the primary investigator and there are some with zero ability to manage people. 
Lack of cooperation between different labs.

pros:
The campus is beautiful and close to downtown Evanston. 

Amazing work life balance, the people here actually care that you're a human being.

Professional development, they want you to grow in your skill set/career. Generous tuition reimbursement.

The culture itself, everyone seems genuinely happy to be here.
cons: It can sometimes be tough to get funding for certain things, but that's to be expected with higher education.

job_title: Business Administrator II in Evanston, IL
pros: Great university to work for. Exceptional benefits and focus on positive work environment.
cons: Once they've been hired it is extremely difficult to dismiss bad employees and so most departments have one or two people who are just putting in hours to get the paycheck.

pros: Pay is reasonable. Benefits are generous.  Work-life balance.  Parking is low cost for area.
cons: Communication with departments are horrendous.  Confusion between different entities that are involved with Hospital.  Child care options provided on Chicago campus are geared towards higher paid staff, not reasonably priced like Evanston campus options.

review_title: Laid back, easy going job but not a career
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Evanston, IL
pros: no stress, no hard deadlines, good work- life balance. decent benefits, benefits of university.
cons: no career path, silo units, no accountability. there might be a career progression in terms of title but you will be doing the same job for 15-20 years

pros:
Beautiful campus. 
Great benefits.
Growth is supported. 
Smart co-workers.
Doing something that makes the world a better place.
Financially stable.
cons:
Leadership is male dominated.
Hard to move to other positions.
Slower environment.
Difficult to move things forward. 
Projects often die on the vine.

pros:
Great benefits, co-workers, 3 weeks vacation to start + 3 personal days. 100% STD, everyone is automatically enrolled.
University is very decentralized, so your experience will really vary based on what college/department you're in. 
Lots of opportunities for advancement/transfer.
cons: Being a university, inefficiency and lower-than-average pay are two cons. But the pros outweigh the cons.

pros:
* Technical freedom
* Flexible work hours
* Amazing retirement benefits
* Meaningful work
* Good people
* Socially progressive
* Smart people to learn from
* Fast growing field
cons:
* Big place
* Strategic goals hard to implement
* Healthcare technical establishment sclerotic
* Silos make it hard to do good work
* Funding mechanisms provide unhealthy incentives

pros: great benefits; the students are awesome and fun to work with; beautiful campus
cons: Unless you are prepared to majorly kiss up to everyone, they will get rid of you for someone who will work at a lower hourly rate.

review_title: Good learning experience, but position has little room for growth
pros:
A well-respected university
Generally, compensation is adequate
Great location
Opportunities to network
Opportunities for continuing education as well as personal learning
cons:
Commute and/or parking 
Very decentralized institution
Work experience tied very closely to direct supervisor
Separation between Medical School and Evanston

pros: Beautiful campus, with plenty of resource for your research. You work with the most experienced kind of researchers and they do help you a lot in every aspect you can imagine.
cons: Well, you need to teach, and then you need to adapt to the need of the undergrads, and they are not that easy to satisfy. Sometimes they just don't want to learn in any sense

job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent employee benefits including health, dental, vision, disability, life insurance, sick days, vacation, personal floating holidays etc. The best are the education benefits; up to $10,000/year for graduate school.
cons: Although the benefits are great, the pay is not as comparable to other sectors. Easy to get locked into one job class or pay for a long period of time, merit increases are less than 3% per year.

review_title: Mostly a good place to work
pros: Employment here comes with decent benefits, a flexible work schedule, and competitive pay.
cons: Staff (including research staff like postdocs and graduate students) are significantly undervalued. The university is more concerned about undergraduate tuition dollars and faculty happiness than they are about anyone else's well being. They also care more about the appearance of racial and gender equity than actually accommodating the needs of minorities and women.

review_title: Great environment and collaboration opportunities in a multidisciplinary research setting.
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Chicago, IL
pros: Medical school campus is right at downtown by the lake, The research facilities are outstanding, and a great collaboration opportunity with the clinicians.
cons: Commuting to NU downtown campus without any train lines in the vicinity could be time-consuming.

pros: I worked at Northwestern for almost 2 years and it was a great experience in my 12 years in Higher Education.  Better than the previous two Universities that I had been employed at.  Benefits, salary, and co-workers were outstanding from my experience.  However, departments are run differently, so not everyone may have the same overall experience that I had.
cons: Employee 'charged' parking monthly fee.

pros: I was a postdoc in the sciences. It is a great learning environment (very lab dependent though). Virtually any instrument you can imagine is available in their use facilities.
cons: It's academia. So the pays sucks, but that is all of academia. The thing I found most annoying was the food options on campus are horrible.

pros: Great career support. Flexible policy for choosing advisor and switch groups. Many interdisciplinary research opportunities. Great location and reputation
cons: Depending on advisor, work life balance can be terrible. It is not unheard of to hear that some advisor requires ~80 hrs per week dedicated to research

pros: Very considerate applying process and system is stable and user friendly. Working environment is great! Would love to continue to study and work at Northwestern University
cons: Actually there is not much advice since I do not have a long time experience...but it’d I have to name one maybe it is the working place . There is no special room prepared for office hours. But generally satisfied

pros: Stellar benefits, intellectually-stimulating work environment, wonderful colleagues
cons: Limited opportunity for advancement, including professional development and promotion (whether salary bump or even an improved title!); expected to take on more responsibilities without necessarily receiving anything in return; longevity seems more important than talent and/or contributions

review_title: Not a bad gig for starting
pros: Good benefits and retirement plan. Welcoming environment and supportive community.
cons: Transparency is lacking, especially from campus leadership. At times faculty really talk down to the staff and I have heard many horror stories. Hiring and salary freezes can also really derail staff morale as essentially you are blocked from

job_title: Research Scientist II in Chicago, IL
pros: Northwestern University Medical School is great place to work and is located in the heart of Chicago, a wonderful multi-ethnic city.
cons: A large university with far too many administrative staff leading to larger overhead cost than that is actually necessary to operate efficiently.

review_title: Great, friendly and cooperative lab to work in!
pros: Lab members are always willing and motivated to help out other members. Heather is an amazing PI who wants all her members to succeed and will do anything necessary to help. She is also always ready to challenge her members.
cons: This lab has grown extremely quickly in the past few years and space has become an issue in the lab.

review_title: Great research environment, in a great city, with excellent compensation.
pros: Excellent benefits and compensation, from an employer that treats its employees very well. Northwestern has the best work environment of the universities where I've been employed.
cons: The Chicago campus is not very convenient, if you don't want to live downtown. Other than that, there are no appreciable cons to working at Northwestern University.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Many well-known professors, if you work in their lab, you will likely have no problem finding a job once you are done.
cons: Too many egos in the department.  The classes were useless because the professors didn't put any effort into teaching.  Overall, the department does not care about students.

review_title: Beware of proud, big-ego, "famous" but disrespectful/angry/controlling professors, do not work with them or for them.
pros: It is a well-known school. There are quite a few religious groups and organizations, which are very good to have.
cons: Northwestern University doesn't protect the postdoc or employee against a bad supervisor. Their protection is on paper and in words but not in action. They protect faculty that have a big ego, very angry demeanor with bad temper, almost nonexistent leadership skills, and not also able to manage themselves well. All that money they receive from faculty is essentially tainted, is not good, yet they make money and funding the #1 factor and place it before ethical values and considerations. This will limit growth of any people who work with such negative faculty as well as can make them psychologically and physically sick. I have seen people who had stomach problems from stress, most likely related to bad management and selfish-supervisory relationships at the workplace.

pros: The pay is way above average for administrative level work. The benefits are great and the culture is incredibly responsive to personal life.
cons: Political, unprofessional, bureacratic, no management or financial expertise. I was surprised at how dysfuctional this university is with regard to its operations.

review_title: Good place to work - Good benefits - not so great salary.
pros: The students are great and the staff is an interesting mix of smart engaging people. New Dean so that means a lot of flux - change for the good.
cons: The trade-off for working with great people is.....lousy pay. You could make much more in industry and some people will stick around forever because it's safe.

pros: Northwestern ha very good infrastructure and employee support on multiple dimensions. There is a strong culture of cooperative learning and many departments and institutes have newsletters; talks; and  conferences. Northwestern supports many types of personal and professional development. Other people like working here, so it's a positive work environment.
cons: Salary is probably lower than at corporate entities, but job security is likely higher.

pros: My experience at Northwestern was one of the best. I was able to learn valuable skills to continue in my career. Coworkers are amazing and the team I worked with was very supportive. My advice: apply there you will love it!
cons: I have no Cons for this company

review_title: Cutting edge institution but below average pay
job_title: Research Study Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Great institution, on the cutting edge in every field (clinical, academic, research et al), offers tons of networking and workplace edu/training opportunities, hires top-notch faculty and staff
cons: Limited advancement, management hesitant to do internal promotions, pay below national average, great for entry-level opportunities but would opt out within a year or two due to aforementioned cons

job_title: Student Assistant, Library IT in Evanston, IL

cons: Not many people work hard which is pretty demotivating. The job can be extremely boring/repetitive at times. Very disorganized department compared to equivalent job at UIUC

job_title: Predoctoral Research Fellow in Evanston, IL
pros: A lot of space to work, facilities are available to conduct the experiences you want to do. People are always ready to help you if you ask. Moreover the neighborhood is very peaceful!
cons: A little bit far away from downtown Chicago so you may pay a lot for a place that is only close to your work but far away from everything else.

review_title: Cheap healthcare and benefits are major perks
job_title: Program Assistant III in Chicago, IL
pros: NU offers great benefits to employees. Reduced tuition for graduate and certificate programs. Childcare available through NU close to Chicago campus. Discounts offered at some gyms, restaurants and retail stores for NU employees.
cons: Low salaries. May not attract as talented employees as corporations. Some processes are out of date and need revision. Some central depts could also need an overhaul.

review_title: Middle of the road academia job-experience
pros:
stimulating intellectual environment
relative bureaucratic efficiency (for academia)
reasonable benefits
intercampus shuttle/transportation benefits
good on-campus fitness facility
cons:
academic lab hierarchies allow toxic management styles to flourish
sexual and mental healthcare below industry standard

review_title: I study at Northwestern for my PhD
cons: the research work is not easy to handle, you should have a strong willpower, office space is limited

job_title: Research Technologist II in Chicago, IL
pros:
Overall, working here was great and the benefit package was really good. Working in the allergy/immunology department had some interesting and fun projects to work on, which allowed me to improve my skills and learn new skills. 
My supervisor was nice.
cons:
Running multiple tests in the day
Was suddenly let go for no particular reason. The supervisor said it was not a good match.

pros: First rate colleagues and environment and a can do approach

job_title: Senior Associate Director in Evanston, IL
pros: prestigious University, very smart people, everyone is passionate about the work

review_title: Northwestern's Feinberg School of Medicine: An excellent place to grow and expand through professional development.
job_title: Director of Research Operations in Chicago, IL
pros: Mission, Location, Healthcare Excellence, Modern Facilities, and a pleasant environment.

review_title: Great place to get a good education, but also need to get ready for the necessary solitude and frustration.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL

review_title: Great school, very competitive and lot of pressure!

review_title: Great learning experience and great mentorship

review_title: Great University at a great location
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL

job_title: Research Study Assistant in Chicago, IL

review_title: Overall good experience working as a graduate student in the sciences.

pros: The current organizational change allows you to be a part of a big vision. Also, working in a department for a University is a unique and meaningful opportunity.

review_title: Good Place to Work. Good chances for moving up, as well as furthering your career with great skill development.

review_title: I am working as an research assistant at Northwestern.

review_title: Diverse community with heavy research focus

pros: The library is a fantastic place to work at Northwestern. Coworkers, both students and adults, have always been friendly and seem to treat each other with a great deal of respect.

pros: Great 401K plan, Flexibility, co-workers, option to join credit union.

pros: Working at Northwestern has been a great experience! In the engineering department, the work environment is fast-paced and somewhat intense.
